{"config":{"server":{"port":3000,"basePath":"","baseUrl":"http://localhost:3000"},"application":{"domain":"juice-sh.op","name":"OWASP Juice Shop","logo":"JuiceShop_Logo.png","favicon":"favicon_js.ico","theme":"bluegrey-lightgreen","showVersionNumber":true,"showGitHubLinks":true,"localBackupEnabled":true,"numberOfRandomFakeUsers":0,"altcoinName":"Juicycoin","privacyContactEmail":"donotreply@owasp-juice.shop","customMetricsPrefix":"juiceshop","chatBot":{"name":"Juicy","greeting":"Nice to meet you , I'm ","trainingData":"botDefaultTrainingData.json","defaultResponse":"Sorry I couldn't understand what you were trying to say","avatar":"JuicyChatBot.png"},"social":{"twitterUrl":"https://twitter.com/owasp_juiceshop","facebookUrl":"https://www.facebook.com/owasp.juiceshop","slackUrl":"https://owasp.org/slack/invite","redditUrl":"https://www.reddit.com/r/owasp_juiceshop","pressKitUrl":"https://github.com/OWASP/owasp-swag/tree/master/projects/juice-shop","nftUrl":"https://opensea.io/collection/juice-shop","questionnaireUrl":null},"recyclePage":{"topProductImage":"fruit_press.jpg","bottomProductImage":"apple_pressings.jpg"},"welcomeBanner":{"showOnFirstStart":true,"title":"Welcome to OWASP Juice Shop!","message":"

Being a web application with a vast number of intended security vulnerabilities, the OWASP Juice Shop is supposed to be the opposite of a best practice or template application for web developers: It is an awareness, training, demonstration and exercise tool for security risks in modern web applications. The OWASP Juice Shop is an open-source project hosted by the non-profit Open Worldwide Application Security Project (OWASP) and is developed and maintained by volunteers. Check out the link below for more information and documentation on the project.

https://owasp-juice.shop

8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.details: This vulnerability allows an attacker to access secret tokens stored in the source code. These tokens should not be publicly available and should be stored securely. Leaking secret tokens can lead to unauthorized access and other security risks.
8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.remedy: Ensure that secret tokens are not stored in the source code and are not publicly available. Use secure storage mechanisms such as environment variables or secure storage services to store secret tokens. Rotate secret tokens regularly to reduce the risk of unauthorized access.
8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.exposure: Gain Privileges or Assume Identity; Leaking Secrets

8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.name: Secret Tokens Leak

To begin, go to the _Login_ page via the _Account_ menu.",fixture:"app-navbar",fixtureAfter:!0,unskippable:!0,resolved:F("login")},{text:"To find a way around the normal login process we will try to use a **SQL Injection** (SQLi) attack.",fixture:"#email",resolved:p(8e3)},{text:"A good starting point for simple SQL Injections is to insert quotation marks (like `\"` or `'`). These mess with the syntax of an insecurely concatenated query and might give you feedback if an endpoint is vulnerable or not.",fixture:"#email",resolved:p(15e3)},{text:"Start with entering `'` in the **email field**.",fixture:"#email",unskippable:!0,resolved:b("#email","'")},{text:"Now put anything in the **password field**. It doesn't matter what.",fixture:"#password",unskippable:!0,resolved:u("#password")},{text:"Press the _Log in_ button.",fixture:"#rememberMe",unskippable:!0,resolved:h("#loginButton")},{text:"Nice! Do you see the red `[object Object]` error at the top? Unfortunately it isn't really telling us much about what went wrong...",fixture:"#rememberMe",resolved:p(1e4)},{text:"Maybe you will be able to find out more information about the error in the JavaScript console or the network tab of your browser!",fixture:"#rememberMe",resolved:p(1e4)},{text:"Did you spot the error message with the `SQLITE_ERROR` and the entire SQL query in the 500 response to `/login`? If not, keep the network tab open and click _Log in_ again. Then inspect the occuring response closely.",fixture:"#rememberMe",resolved:p(3e4)},{text:"Let's try to manipulate the query a bit to make it useful. The query is still invalid? Can you see why from the new error in the HTTP response?",fixture:"#rememberMe",resolved:p(8e3)},{text:"We need to make sure that the rest of the query after our injection doesn't get executed. Any Ideas?",fixture:"#rememberMe",resolved:p(8e3)},{text:"You can comment out anything after your injection payload from query using comments in SQL. In SQLite databases you can use `--` for that.",fixture:"#rememberMe",resolved:p(1e4)},{text:"So, type in `' OR true--` into the email field.",fixture:"#email",unskippable:!0,resolved:b("#email","' OR true--")},{text:"Press the _Log in_ button again and sit back...",fixture:"#rememberMe",unskippable:!0,resolved:h("#loginButton")},{text:"That worked, right?! 8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.details: This vulnerability allows an attacker to access secret tokens stored in the source code. These tokens should not be publicly available and should be stored securely. Leaking secret tokens can lead to unauthorized access and other security risks.
8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.remedy: Ensure that secret tokens are not stored in the source code and are not publicly available. Use secure storage mechanisms such as environment variables or secure storage services to store secret tokens. Rotate secret tokens regularly to reduce the risk of unauthorized access.
8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.exposure: Gain Privileges or Assume Identity; Leaking Secrets

8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.name: CSS Injection

8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.details: The target application does not properly sanitize user input, allowing attackers to inject malicious Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) code. This vulnerability can lead to various security risks, such as defacing the website, extracting sensitive information, or causing denial of service for legitimate users. By injecting malicious CSS code, an attacker can manipulate the appearance and behavior of a web page, potentially tricking users into revealing confidential information or exploiting vulnerabilities in the underlying code. This can be exploited through input fields, form submissions, or other user-generated content that is not properly validated or sanitized.
8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.remedy: Ensure that all user-generated content is properly validated and sanitized before being processed by the web application. Implement input validation and output encoding to prevent malicious CSS code from being injected into the application. Use secure coding practices to sanitize user input and escape special characters to prevent CSS injection attacks.
8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.exposure: Read Application Data; Website Defacement; Denial of Service

8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.details: Strict-Transport-Security header is a security feature that lets a web site tell browsers that it should only be accessed using HTTPS, instead of using HTTP. A missing header can allow an attacker to bypass the protection mechanism. Exploiting this vulnerability can lead to a wide range of cryptographic attacks and private data leakage.
8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.remedy:
Ensure that the Strict-Transport-Security header is set to the correct value. The header should be set to one of the following options:
1. Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=<expire-time>
2. Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=<expire-time>; includeSubDomains
3. Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=<expire-time>; preload

8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.name: Missing Content-Security-Policy Header

8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.details: Content-Security-Policy header controls the resources that a user agent is allowed to load for a given page. A missing header can allow an attacker to bypass the protection mechanism. Exploiting this vulnerability can lead to a wide range of attacks such as Cross-Site Scripting (XSS).
8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.remedy: Ensure that the Content-Security-Policy header is set to the correct value. The header should be set to the appropriate value to prevent the browser from loading resources from untrusted sources. For example, script-src 'self' will only allow scripts to be loaded from the same origin. This header needs to be set to the appropriate value based on the application's requirements there is no one-size-fits-all solution.

8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.name: Misconfigured Access-Control-Allow-Origin Header

8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.details: Access-Control-Allow-Origin header controls which origins are allowed to access the resources of a site. A misconfigured header can allow an attacker to bypass the protection mechanism. Exploiting this vulnerability can lead to a wide range of attacks such as Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF).
8DATCC1RmYRk4CEf6tNKSH.remedy: Ensure that the Access-Control-Allow-Origin header is set to the correct value. The header should be set to the origin of the request or to a list of trusted origins. Avoid using the wildcard (*) value unless the resource is intended to be public such as a public API or a static resouse like CSS or JavaScript.
